abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Sewerage and
            Water Reuse Project for Morocco was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both unsatisfactory. Lessons learned from the project:
            Contingency planning might have prepared the parties to
            trigger the restructuring as early as 1999 (midterm review)
            and avoid the subsequent suspension controversy. The Project
            would have reached better outcomes faster, and Bank and
            Borrower would have incurred lesser costs, if the
            restructuring had taken place earlier. While framed to
            support an ambitious national vision to rehabilitate and
            develop the sanitation sector, project preparation was not
            sufficiently concerned with the technical details and
            institutional realities crucial to implementation in Fez.
            The project did not involve public health specialists in
            preparation or supervision. While the project aimed at
            institutional and performance gains, it lacked a strategy
            and components to influence such objectives. Even with a
            less ambitious restructured scope, indicators provided in
            this report show that the population of Fez is better off
            with the project than without it.
